children.value: shadertools is a GLSL shader module system built around a GLSL "assembler" that allows you build modular shaders. It addresses the lack of a module/import system in the GLSL language and allows you to import chunks of reusable shader code from modules into your shader source code, and organize your shader code in reusable modules.
Enables you to import and "inject" prepackaged modules of shader code into your shaders.
Allows you to package up reusable GLSL code as shader modules.
Adds GPU detection and a measure of portability your shaders.
To add/inject existing modules into your shaders, just add the modules parameter to your
To create a new shader module, you need to create a descriptor object.
This object can be used as shader module directly:

children.value: - a set of generic GLSL functions that can be included either in a fragment shader or a vertex shader (or both). The
module is a good example of this type of module.
- Contains specific vertex and/or fragment shader "chunks", often set up so that the vertex shader part sets up a
used by the fragment shader part.
To define a new shader module, you create a descriptor object that brings together all the necessary pieces:
Descriptor objects can define the following fields:
, Required) - The name of the shader module.
JavaScript function that maps JavaScript parameter keys to uniforms used by this module
) - injections the module will make into shader hooks, see below
) - a list of other shader modules that this module is dependent on
will scan GLSL source code for the deprecated constructs and issue a console warning if found. Each API is described in the following format:
: whether the old API is still supported.
The GLSL code for a shader module typically contains:
a mix of uniform and varying declarations
one or more GLSL function definitions
Each shader module provides a method to get a map of uniforms for the shader. This function will be called with two arguments:
- the module settings to update. This argument may not be provided when
is called to generate a set of default uniform values.
- the uniforms generated by this module's dependencies.
The function should return a JavaScript object with keys representing uniform names and values representing uniform values.
The function should expect the shape of the dependency uniforms to vary based on what's passed in
. This behavior is intended because we only want to recalculate a uniform if the uniforms that it depends on are changed. An example is the
will receive the updated projection matrix generated by the

If the uniforms of this module can be directly pulled from user settings, they may declaratively defined by a
At runtime, this map will be used to generate the uniforms needed by the shaders. If either
is present in the user's module settings, then the user's value will be used; otherwise, the default value in the original definition will be used.
Each uniform definition may contain the following fields:
- the default value of this uniform
, the following additional fields may be added for validation:
A map of hook function signatures to either the injection code string, or an object containing the injection code and an
option indicating ordering within the hook function. See
documentation for more information on shader hooks.

Where possible, the shader assembler replaces keywords based on the version of the shader into which a module is inserted. While not all GLSL ES 3.0 features can be emulated, this allows many modules to be used across versions.
